The stuff we leave in space, on planets and on the moon will show evidence of our existence a lot longer than most stuff left on earth.

Two things overlooked in this video:

- our most undegradable waste is... glass
Glass last only a little 6 000 years before getting chewed by Nature.
So a comparable evolved society like ours, would left no trace or artifact of its activities after 10 000 years since the last produced waste.
Everything like cities, cars or nuclear powerplants would crumble to dust and be scattered everywhere, making it "natural" for the next intelligent species to come after.

- Pyramids aren't immortal
Go check the first drawings about pyramids from napoleonian times.
There were basically buried under the sand. It took decades to get the sphinx out of it and to present it the way it is today. Same for the Inca/Aztec civilizations, literally devored by forests in the span of a few centuries. What about Celtic Empire in central Europe? Lost to history, with some tumulus and lots of questionable interpretations.
With an optimistic take, any big monument we could produce would last less than 10 000 years.

With that in mind, any pre-human civilization would appear then disappear in a matter of, let's be optimistic again, 400 000 years?

Note than the year 2k for neanderthalians were 120 000 years ago.
Which also happened to witness a climate change, just like we witness in our industrial age.

Saying it only took less than 10 000 years (110 000 years ago) for hi-tech neanderthal to get to space and leave tribal-like fellows (like our amazonian tribes) behind, isn't that far fetched.
All we could get from our human point of view, are scattered neanderthal primitive fossils... and nothing more.

The point is, as suggested in the video about identifying civilizations as such, if we only expect hunter-gatherers, we'll only find hunter-gatherers.
What about looking for cyborgs in tuxedo suit?

How could we assess that the current level of natural ressources on Earth is indeed the natural expected amount, and not what remains after several previous civilizations scienced the sh*t out of it?
The lack of helium3 on Earth compared to the Moon might be an indicator "someone" already mined it on our planet for their fusion reactors, eons before us.
The abondance of metals, rare or not, in asteroids compared to the difficulty to mine it on Earth, might not just be the result of tectonic activities. But also the indication that every "easy" earthian spots to mine were already mined, far before we were even able to draw a circle on a grotto wall.

Under this, is a bigger ego issue: just because we are the last in the so-called tree of evolution, we surely must be the most intelligent and able of the earthian lot.

Except there is no objective reason why it should be the case.

Some of the previous "homo" had the same physical characteristics and environnemental settings as we did. For what reason they would have performed poorer than us, despite the same span of time?

Last time I've checked, homo "sapiens" wasted most of its civilized time and energy in religious wars and senseless bigotery.
While, from the current state of knowledge, neanderthal never had the "faith" defect in his brain, to impede his technological progress with incoherent beliefs.

If we want to find proof of other advanced civilizations, we should look not on Earth, but in space.
Phobos and Deimos would be the remnant of asteroid mining. And thus still offer traces of artificial exploitation, if not complete structures.
Ancient probes should still be in one piece in the Oort cloud.

There is a fun theory i heard about. Basically a great flood is reference in a lot of different cultures which could have been a results of a comet hitting earth causing massive changes in the climate leading to the dying off of multiple megafauna. This would have supposedly occurred 12,000-10,000 years ago predating the Sumerian Empire.

When this great disaster happened, it caused a massive reset in human culture. An “advance” civilization that had the ability to travel the sea with great accuracy, an ability we didn’t even perfect until the 1800s, was essentially erased from history.

Why do we think this is a possibility? Well, i forget how but a map maker in the early 1500s was making a world map using smaller maps, some up which were very old, but not only that, were from the Library of Alexandria. One of this maps display Antarctica on the bottom of it when it hadn’t been discovered yet, it also accurately depicted a land formation that, when the maps were made in the 1500s, were already well under water.

So that’s one piece of evidence, other things that suggest an older “advance” civilization is obviously all this ancient structures that we have no clue how they were built. These structures from across the globe across many ancient cultures have similar architecture and similar beliefs about life after death.

The Amazon is currently reveal a lost civilization with genetic information that shouldn’t be there with our current understanding of human migrations.

The whole thing comes together as
1. An decently advance sea faring cultures existed give or take 10,000+ years ago.

2. A great desastre occurred causing a drastic changes in the environment

3. Advance humans lost there society as a whole and left as refugees to the Hunter-Gather tribes since they knew how to live off the land.

4. As these survivors spread out across the world in search of refuge, they brought along their culture, beliefs, and most importantly, knowledge.

5. Many of this new refugees were view as “supernatural” because of their advance knowledge. Some may have became known as “Civilization Bringers”. Myths or legends may have been inspired by this people trying to spread the knowledge of the lost civilization. These people could be the inspiration for “The Handbags Of The Gods” seen depicted in stone across many Ancient Monuments around the world.

These is just a fun theory. I’m not saying this is true or fact. Simply compiling knowledge of the past.

I've thought about this one a lot and it really is incredibly unlikely for two points: natural resource usage and evolution.

The time it takes for fossil fuels to replenish would mean any prior industrial civilization would have to have died out (or stopped using fossil fuels) many millions of years ago — long before brains were advanced enough.

There's also the fact that we see other intelligent species today that have the brain sophistication for culture and potentially even language, like in porpoises and sperm whales. Yet they don't have civilizations, and I feel like the main reason is that they don't need to because of how well they already fit their niches, and that civilization is something that isn't objectively "superior" or the expected advancement of any intelligent enough species but a very human, very primate means of coping, and one which presents challenges to itself that cause it to expand via competition (agriculture requires land, land is finite, different villages wage conflict over land, larger ones coalesce into governments, more technologically sophisticated governments dominate, etc.) What we've created as civilizations is impressive, and the main factor of differentiation beyond just intelligence is our ability to use tools with fine dexterity. Other species could develop intelligence higher than ours yet never leave hunter-gatherer status because they didn't need to evolve the things we needed to. Our ability to reach outer space is as much owed to our fingers as it is to intelligence.

So what we see today with human society isn't really all that bespoken of our intelligence (which is still highest of all animals, not to ignore that fact) but of simply time running its course through our unique system of adaptation and self-competition and happenstance of biological form allowing fine manipulation.
The past has been dug up sufficiently to lay to rest any conjectures about aliens or lost civilizations in the past.  It's pure escapism to think otherwise.

Before I watch this, I can give the correct answer: NO. I live in Michigan, USA. In the northern part of Michigan, are two metal containing rock formations that any previous Lost Civilizations would have mined and humans would not have found them intact. One is in the Keweenaw Peninsula where ancient lava flows were produced during the Mesoproterozoic Era as a part of the Midcontinent Rift between 1.096 and 1.087 billion years ago. This volcanic activity produced the only strata on Earth where large-scale economically recoverable 97 percent pure native copper is found. This copper was mined between 1870 and 1910. The other is the Animikie Group, found in  both Michigan and Minnesota. This rock formation was laid down between 2.200 to 1.850 billion years ago. It contains thick, 50%-iron, layers and has produced the vast majority of iron mined in the United States. Both of the geologic sites formed long before multicellular life evolved. In fact the iron in Animikie Group is part of the total removal of dissolved iron from the ocean by molecular oxygen, after which the oxygen began to accumulate in the atmosphere, and without that gaseous oxygen it is impossible for there to be animal life on land, thus this iron ore body was in place before any possible Lost Civilization. The fact that it was not mined before humans found it means there was no prior Lost Civilization.

Some of our satellites are in orbits that will last for hundreds of millions of years (think Geosynchronous). Other space probes that are expected to last for 2 billion years (think voyager and new horizons). satellites that orbit the sun rather than the Earth that should maintain their orbits for billions of years. And moon debris from apollo and other missions that should last a few hundred million as well (no decay on the moon other than from meteorites and solar rays). If there were other civilizations that reached our levels we might not be able to detect them on Earth due to geological and biological cycles. But their space debris would be still be noticeable being absent from such processes. Since we have found no evidence of such ancient space debris we have evidence that no ancient civilizations ever reached our level of industrialization that allowed for space travel.

In short, we can say we likely are the only advanced civilization to have lived on Earth due to a lack of evidence for any other civilizations. But we can say with confidence we are the most advanced civilization to have ever lived on Earth if there were others.

There are recent enough technology ambiguities that defy easy explanation.    They are accessible, many in museums.   The Antikythera mechanism is a single example of technology that should not have been possible 2100 years ago, and it re-wrote/destroyed a bunch of historic presumptions.    Megalithic stone structures with sub-millimeter machining, flat surfaces of exceptional quality,  evident saw marks and drill core marks,  and of gargantuan size ( some exceeding 1000 tons), and some of those on mountain ridges...     inexplicable.    I'm not suggesting aliens nor Atlanteans, but the artifacts themselves scream that our presumptions about the ancients are wildly off mark.

Mariupol. Bevor diesem Winter war die Stadt sicher, gemütlich und florierend. Bevor diesem Winter lachte Ortsansässigen, klangen Meer und Seemöwe. Bevor dem Krieg lebten die Menschen hier. Aber bei russischem Angriff ist alles in einem Moment zusammengebrochen.
Am 9. März bombardierten russische Okkupationstruppen Kinderkrankenhaus und Entbindungsheim in Mariupol absichtlich. Wegen des Beschusses starben 3 Menschen, es gab 17 Verletzten. Eine schwangere Frau mit ihrem ungeborenen Kind überlebten nicht.
Nicht nur Krankenhäuser und Entbindungsheime sondern auch Schulen, Kindergarten und Kulturgebäude sind Ziele für russische Anschläge. Am 16. März warfen die russischen Soldaten eine Superbombe auf Schauspielhaus im Stadtzentrum, wo hunderte Menschen sich zum Zeitpunkt des Anschlags befanden. Am 19. März litt eine Kunstschule, in der sich rund 400 Menschen, darunter Kinder, Frauen und ältere Leute, befanden, an einer Beschießung.
Ungefähr 20 tausend Zivilisten sind in Mariupol während der russischen Blockade gestorben.
Allerdings hören Okkupationstruppe mit Beschuss und ständigem Terror nicht auf. Mariupols Einwohner werden in Filtrationslager geschickt, wo sie ihre Handys und Dokumente abgeben müssen. Später erhalten einige der Deportieren Besatzungsausweise und werden in abgelegene Städte Russlands geschickt. Dieser Schritt ähnelt sich Sowjetischen Deportationsoperationen.
Nach allen Tatsachen und Zahlen entsteht eine Frage: Kämpfen russische Truppen gegen schwangere Frauen, künftige geborene Kinder oder Senioren? Ich kann kaum eine andere Antwort, die verschieden von der ist, finden: Das ist blanker Terror und zielbewusstes Genozid der Ukrainer.

The archeological record pointing to the agricultural revolution 10,000 years ago is something that is definitely worth looking into more. The Younger Dryas Impact Hypothesis is a very credible perspective on many archeological outliers that do not conform to this narrative of "97% hunter gather history, 3% agricultural". Basically, geological features across Washington, Canada, and Europe point towards the fact that a comet rained down upon Earth about 12,000 years ago in sufficiently large chunks to cause cataclysmic outcomes. The cited narrative about our agricultural past only restricts the funding of projects that seek to dig beyond these geological time points and explore what came before. Graham Hancock's and Randall Carlson's work  are worth exploring if this interests you!

6:00 No matter how intelligent we know cephalopods to be, I think it's very unlikely for water-based life to develop sapience and become an advanced civilization. Water just has properties that stand in the way too much. The viscosity makes tool usage difficult because water resists the act of hitting things hard. The only tools that could work fine are spears, and knapping flint for spearheads is also difficult because of the viscosity. Water also stores more thermal energy, so seasons change the environment less, and the animal needs to have less ingenuity to survive harsh conditions, lessening the evolutionary pressure of developing more intelligence. Most importantly, however, fire is impossible underwater. Human brain development accelerated because of the invention of cooking. Outsourcing part of the digestive process to an external energy source made food release more nutrients in the body, allowing there to be more fuel for a larger brain. It is simply more likely for cephalopods to live comfortably in the state they are without becoming sapient, just like what sharks have done for millions of years.

You did forget one thing that would stay for an incredibly long time and be almost impossible to miss, space debris. Satellites above low Earth orbits will basically stay there forever and so will any satellites we've put in orbit of other bodies like the sun or other planets, probes and other stuff that we've left behind on extra terrestrial bodies can also stay around for very long. Everything that's been left on the moon for example will basically have to be hit by asteroids to be removed and with how much we've left and how low the rate of asteroid impacts is in our current solar system they'll basically stay there forever, immune to biological or atmospheric sources of decay. These things would be obvious tell tale signs of a previous industrial civilization and even if many of the satellites are destroyed due to Kepler syndrome it still wouldn't be difficult to recognize that these are artificial in nature. Any alien civilization that finds Earth before it is destroyed by the Sun will be able to spot and recognize these things and from that can easily extrapolate that there was once an industrial civilization on Earth, following the same logic given that it only took about 150 years from the invention of the steam engine to the launch of the first artificial satellite we can assume that any industrial civilization in Earth's past would probably have developed space technology and as such leave tell tale evidence in the form of satellites.

There's of course other things we can look at to say that there probably hasn't been any industrial civilization in Earth's past, for example our extraction of hydrocarbons in the form of coal and oil is very noticeable and we have almost used up the entire supply of oil and have significantly reduced the supply of coal. Given how easy these are to use to power machinery we can kinda reason that just because we find them in amounts that are only consistent with us being the first to use them that probably means that there hasn't been any industrial civilization before us. Our coal deposits for example age back to the Carboniferous and many of our oil deposits started developing in later periods. We know that oil would take at least a few hundred million years to naturally regenerate to our current levels and the kind of coal formation that happened during the Carboniferous can't really happen anymore so we can reason with a lot of confidence that there haven't been any industrial civilizations prior to ours.

These videos do have a lot of effort put into both the scientific research and animation, though I have to wonder how much effort is out into the anthropological research? The use of the word "indigenous" is very interesting in this video, because it pops up repeatedly, although it's mostly to describe something called "indigenous aliens"... An oxymoron if I've ever heard one. I understand what you mean by that, but perhaps you meant "ancient indigenous peoples"? Which leads me a subject I've been meaning to dive into for a while.

"Civilized society" is setting our world on fire.

The perspective on science, technology and "civilization" are intrinsically tied together. After all, Galileo came from a civilized society, as did the scientific method and the vast majority of technological and scientific progress that we have today. Except, "civilized" is a very funny term, as it is always people who call themselves civilized who get to define it.

"Civilized society" is setting our world on fire.

Galileo was tried by the inquisition for his scientific findings. Throughout history, knowledge was something that "civilized" society went out of their way to suppress and destroy. How much could we have gained from China, if only there wasn't so much conflict between dynasties? How much could we have learned from Egypt, if the library of Alexandria was not destroyed? What could we have learned about society, if the Nazis didn't burn books on communism and gender theory?

"Civilized society" is setting our world on fire.

And this is from "civilized society?" The same societies that invaded /actually/ indigenous lands, genociding, raping, torturing, enslaving and acting as cruel as humanly possible. That's civilization? Societies that decide to go to war with other nations, causing the deaths of millions of civilians, because of political gain? Claiming it all in the name of religion?

"Civilized society" is setting our world on fire.

Even if you don't care about petty squabbles between people what about the way "civilized society" is treating the earth? The one place we call home? The easiest place for us to live, somewhere that is so comparatively hospitable that we evolved without intervention from intelligent life forms. Somewhere we don't have to terraform, we don't have to have generations of people inside a pod in space just to REACH the damn place. What are we doing to our home?

It's being destroyed. Quite deliberately. Fossil fuel is far from the most efficient source of energy, and it's been that way for almost a century. We've known, to an accurate measure, since the beginning of the industrial revolution, what would happen if we keep burning coal and oil.

"Civilized society" is setting our world on fire.

The sound pollution from ships is eventually going to kill everything in the ocean of we don't stop. Certain parts of the ocean are going to be irradiated longer than humanity because of nuclear arms testing. You might think that's fine, since "nothing lives there" but for bikini island, that's not true. Indigenous people used to live there, and we're forcibly removed by Americans after world war 2.

"Civilized society" is setting our world on fire.

Industrialists, politicians, scientists and billionaires alike won't shut up about setting up a "Mars colony" as if that could ever be a good thing. What would /really/ be the purpose to a Mars colony? A Dyson sphere? Sure, it might be possible, but the possibility of technology is NOT the same thing as the best possible outcome. We've had trains for hundreds of years now, but "civilized society" can't figure out how to stop using cars. We won't have trains and buses everywhere they need to be, until cars don't need to be. Same with a Dyson sphere. We have all the energy we need, why would we need to enslave the fucking SUN for our energy needs?

Technology follows society, not the other way around. Until we fix our societal problems, we will NEVER be able to achieve what humanity is capable of, because "civilized society" is SETTING OUR FUCKING WORLD ON FIRE. WE CAN'T MAKE A DYSON SPHERE IF WE'RE ALL DEAD. WE CAN'T MEET ALIEN "CIVILIZATIONS" IF WE'RE ALL DEAD. And this isn't some vague problem for future people, we're living through it NOW. WE CAN DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT /NOW/. In MY lifetime ALONE I will be lucky to live 80 years without seeing everything die around me.

Don't get me wrong, I love technology and science, but like I said: it follows society. We have MUCH bigger issues than trying to figure out if some hypothetical bullshit is possible. If you wanna know if "Indigenous aliens" used to live on earth but were wiped out, why don't you try talking to some indigenous HUMANS who are on the verge of being wiped out. Talk to the people who might have an interest in preserving not only humanity, but the fucking planet we live on.

Science is the field of "what we can prove". Even up to a high probability, science ignores facts and calls it pseudoscience or plain wrong. It must be irrefutable before it is accepted as science. Fair enough.

Archaeologists digging in Indonesia found in the last 25 years or so, a pyramid covered over with dust, volcanic ash, flora, etc. and now looked more like a hill. The team dug down with core drills and extracted samples. What they found was the pyramid was built over numerous times, slowly getting bigger with each new layer. They found carbon between the layers which could be dated. The lowest levels of coring they reached before the Indonesian government shut them down was 25,000 years old ! But it's not science.

This overview of the evolution of life on Earth only reinforces the absurdity of the evolution theory, which is based on a bunch of speculative assumptions and very little evidence, if any at all. According to this theory, they want us to believe that we as humans have been around for just a few hundred thousand years, 97% of the time being very primitive, 2.9% farmers, and less than 1% industrial, while life on Earth is hundreds of millions of years old. It's ridiculous to think that such progression of the most sophisticated species on the planet would happen so suddenly, with no apparent reason and in such a short span of time.

As a matter of fact, I do find it reasonable to speculate that some more advanced civilization may have come about much earlier on Earth, maybe from some other planet, and helped local creatures to develop and evolve over time, maybe by genetic manipulation, hybridization, and training. The so-called Ancient Aliens theory. This would explain why different ancient cultures had similar beliefs in gods that descended from the heavens and adopted similar advanced architecture while living apart and never having encountered one another.

Something else that's been on my mind is that, as scientists are continuing their search for extraterrestrial life, or "aliens", they are looking only for things that are like us. When you hear about aliens being looked for, it almost always starts or ends with, "Earth-like planets located in the habitable zone of their star. We even can see this at 0:21 - 0:32. Scientists have only been looking in places that could potentially harbor life similar to us, so then the question becomes, what are we looking for? Is it aliens/extraterrestrial life in any form, or is it human-like intelligent life that obey laws that are similar to ours? If the answer is the first, then we need to expand our searches to planets of all types, not just planets that are located in the "habitable zone" of stars, because to other intelligent or non-intelligent life out there, water could be a concept/thing they've never even heard of let alone need to survive, and we could be completely disregarding/overlooking something that could lead us a step closer.

Why do people always assume and say that people advanced at EXACTLY the same time. All humans on the face of the earth 100,000 years ago didn’t all suddenly become farmers at the same time. That makes zero sense and is extremely unlikely. Look at the difference between Africa and the United States. We are living in the same time and look at the difference in not only civilization but how we have affected our land respectively. Secondly there is no way in hell there was a sudden boom where all single celled organisms just became multicellular. Science always makes false assumptions just to simply things or try to explain it without having proof. People believe all these scientific theories without even questioning the reality of the chances that it really happened that way. I have nothing against this channel I really enjoy watching and the animations are excellent. I just wanted to share my opinion and see if anyone felt the same way. Too many scientific theories and thoughts of the past are so wrong but people don’t question it whatsoever. Just like assuming people went through evolution. Evolution would not affect all humans across the planet in the same way if evolution truly made humans into what they are today there would be MAJOR differences in humans as in different species of humans, humans in mid- evolution, and humans in far less evolved states. Yes you could argue the less evolved humans would have died out but it still doesn’t explain how all humans are relatively similar. It would be the same for animals also. Lastly there’s the whole argument about dinosaurs how scientists just assume what they look like based on what we find in fossils but no one knows exactly what a dinosaur really looked like and for all we know what we know of dinosaurs today could be completely wrong we could be throwing bones together in completely random ways that looked nothing like animals from the past and even if after everything that’s been said and know whether the dinosaurs were real or not where the hell are all the in between species? If we find dinosaur remains where are the human remains from those time periods. People claim humans lived 10,000 years ago then they claim it was actually 200,000 years ago then they claim we had cousin species.. WHERES THE PROOF. So many things about our history don’t make sense and until someone provides some absolutely concrete evidence that the past was how (insert scientist name here) claimed it was   I don’t think people should be so quick to accept things as facts. Always use your own judgment and remember we all have minds we all have the ability to think and use common sense so believe what you want. 6:00 No matter how intelligent we know cephalopods to be, I think it's very unlikely for water-based life to develop sapience and become an advanced civilization. Water just has properties that stand in the way too much. The viscosity makes tool usage difficult because water resists the act of hitting things hard. The only tools that could work fine are spears, and knapping flint for spearheads is also difficult because of the viscosity. Water also stores more thermal energy, so seasons change the environment less, and the animal needs to have less ingenuity to survive harsh conditions, lessening the evolutionary pressure of developing more intelligence. Most importantly, however, fire is impossible underwater. Human brain development accelerated because of the invention of cooking. Outsourcing part of the digestive process to an external energy source made food release more nutrients in the body, allowing there to be more fuel for a larger brain. It is simply more likely for cephalopods to live comfortably in the state they are without becoming sapient, just like what sharks have done for millions of years.

Are their Alien Civilizations? No.
However the timeline of humanity is hilariously skewed.

Most people think the first "civilization" was Mesopotamia when Cities existed for thousands of years before even that.

You don't just "Come up" with something so revolutionary in 1 lifetime.

The German Empire was based on the Roman empire
Which was based on the Greek and Carthaginian empires
Which were based on Egypt
Which was based on older Egypt
Which was based on Assyria
Which was based on Mesopotamia
Which was based on major cities before even then.

The first major "cities" probably evolved over 12,000 years ago (10,000 BC/BCE) which would have been based on agriculture even before then.
Only reason we don't see these older cities is due to destruction, reusing materials, uninterested archeologists or biodegradable building material such as wood (Sahara was Tropical region 20,000-10,000 years ago)

People posting about our satellites orbiting our earth remaining don't realize that none of the satellites that orbit earth are out of earths atmosphere. Most satellites orbiting earth are in the thermosphere. But the rest that are orbiting earth further out are still in earths atmosphere. They would all eventually slow down and fall back towards earth. Telescopes like the James T Webb would eventually be knocked from its orbit as the moon moves causing a shift in its orbit that would eventually knock it off course, but that would take a long time. It is possible that some satellites that aren't in orbits to be found, however they too would eventually change shape from the particles in space bombarding them over millions of years. It would also get harder to trace their origins the longer it's been and the further they get from earth.

It's important to note, that scientists usually overstate and overestimate their ability. Scientific knowledge doesn't mean logic or rational reasoning. For example, if civilzation were to disappear from earth today, leaving no geological trace, but scientists knew what the average CO2 amount was in the atmosphere before civilation, they may be able to deduce chemicals were pumped into the air. However, like in reality, if given no hints or data in the same example, scientists would just assume the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere right now is typical of the planet, even if it's not. They would be unable to distinguish natural from artificial. You can design tests to validate idea with additional knowledge and hindsight, but they cannot determine much when it comes to fluid, complex, natural processes like life, environment, and geology.

If there was proof of an ancient civilization on earth, scientists would only be able to detect it if it was recent, and outrageously similar to our own. It's nearly a guarantee from a logical perspective that other intelligent civilations would develop entirely different culture, societies, technology and habits than us, and therefore most scientists are simply too ignorant or narrow-minded to detect any intelligent life that is not directly in front of them. That's not to say science is ill-equipped, it's not. Science should always lead to the truth. Our current level of scientific advancement, and most mainstream scientists theories are still to primitive to deal with questions as big or as intricate as these. Maybe in 100-200 years.

Do plastics really take hundreds of millions of years to degrade? I thought it was more on the order of hundreds of years...

A vitreous toilet bowl, or vitreous electrical insulator, would last as long as some metamorphic rocks (and which it is an artificial form of) and the oldest of the natural metamorphic rocks is 4 billion years (the Acasta Gneiss). The best places to look would be cratons, which are the remaining chunks of past supercontinents, and are found in certain parts of Australia, South Africa and Canada. There are many millions/billions of such artefacts so even a minute fraction of them surviving in such refuges would eventually lead to their discovery. So that's industrial civilizations of the past. If we take the next step and consider early space=faring civilizations then the best place to look would be the Moon, Mars, and other solar system bodies whose surface might have lasted for billions of years.

I don't think plastics are going to last that long. There is this really common idea that plastics will never degrade, but they are organic after all, organisms will(and have) found ways to break them down for energy. What might even happen is eventually organisms will thrive on plastics as they're an abundant food source, then as the amount of plastic in the environment dwindles, organisms will evolve to produce plastic as an energy storage biomolecule. While plastic is far less efficient in storing energy than fats, carbs, or proteins, the fact that organisms are already producing enzymes capable of breaking it down means there's a selective drive toward it. We might even eventually seen plastics incorporated into the polysaccharide layers that make up biotic colonies, then as those colonies specialize, they may become lichen-like. It wouldn't surprise me if in the far distant future, there's even more plastic than there is today, since the aforementioned organisms would thrive, but diversify fast as it's an entirely untapped biological niche, something that hasn't existed in hundreds of millions of years. As these new plastic organisms thrived, the only thing that could break them down is more of the same organism or cousin species, meaning there's massive evolutionary pressures. As the diversity of plastic life increases, they'll eventually take over and there will be more plastic than ever before in Earths history.

I’m sure the comments section will be chalk-full of Graham Hancock and Mystery History infantry, as well it should be. But let me just say this; you glossed over a truly gargantuan body of physical evidence of advanced ancient civilizations from before (at least) the Younger-Dryas. The megalithic sites alone are all but indisputable and speak not only to the vastly superior capabilities but global interconnectedness of a civilization that mainstream archaeology has no name for. This is to say nothing of the scattered fringe anomalies, such as fossilized hammers in million year old coal strata or the ancient African nuclear reactor. To ignore these kinds of examples does your channel a disservice, and far from reinforcing the mainstream historical narrative during this lay-persons renaissance of interest in such topics, relegates you to the tired stack of mainstream apologist mouthpieces for which there is little to no public demand. You’re not quelling conspiracies or countering misinformation here; you’re just making Kurtzgesagt less relevant - which is truly tragic.

Yilan County Council in Taiwan passed a cross-party motion on December 24 to support the Universal Declaration on Combating and Preventing Forced Organ Harvesting (UDCPFOH). The motion condemns the organ harvesting by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and urges the Taiwan government to implement laws to help end the atrocity.


Chang Chiu-ming, a member of Yilan County Council, said a motion was passed on December 24 against organ harvesting.

When the 76th United Nations General Assembly took place in New York in September 2021, five nongovernmental organizations from the US, Europe, and Asia issued UDCPFOH on September 26, the last day of the World Summit on Combating and Preventing Forced Organ Harvesting.

UDCPFOH has been supported by parliament members, government officials, and leaders from many countries. They include Changrok Soh, member of UN Human Rights Council, and Thierry Valle, director of European Federation for Freedom of Belief. It was also endorsed by Arthur Caplan, professor of bioethics at New York University and the founding director of the Medical Ethics Division.

The Taiwan Falun Gong Human Rights Working Group has since contacted the central government as well as county-level governments in Taiwan, urging them to support this initiative. The Group believes that by raising awareness to the general public and taking further actions, leaders from around the world can stop the CCP’s organ harvesting through joint efforts.

During an ad hoc session held by Yilan County Council on December 24, the motion was initiated by three council members including Zhang Chiu-ming, Chen Han-chung, and Tsai Chin-hui. To fulfill its human rights commitment, the motion aims to support the UDCPFOH, condemn the organ harvesting atrocity by the CCP, and institute related criminal legislation. For specific implementation of this resolution, the council requests the county government to contact relevant agencies of the Taiwan Executive Yuan. With 25 cosponsors, including Wu Hong-mo and Yang Tree, this motion was passed in the council.

Chang said he was happy to see Yilan Council supporting the upright with this motion. Yang pointed out the CCP’s brutality of organ harvesting is anti-humanity and it is a disgrace to mankind. He hopes such efforts will stop the atrocity and promote kindness as well as traditional values in society.

Personally, I think it is almost impossible that there was a species before us that developed a technically advanced society. That would have been a global society that would have left its mark on the earth and perhaps also on nearby space, consuming massive amounts of primary energy sources and raw materials (especially metals).
I'm not so sure about a pre-industrial society on a level at most like 250 years ago. It is purely speculative, but from my point of view it is not impossible. But since the whole thing would have to have happened a very long time ago, we can rule out the possibility that such a species would have emerged from the primate group, probably not even from modern mammals. The diapside archosaur lineage would be my hottest guess. Or the therapsid predecessors of the mammals. In other words, most likely in the Late Permian or Late Cretaceous. "Most likely" is perhaps the wrong term, more appropriate would be "least unlikely".

You did forget one thing that would stay for an incredibly long time and be almost impossible to miss, space debris. Satellites above low Earth orbits will basically stay there forever and so will any satellites we've put in orbit of other bodies like the sun or other planets, probes and other stuff that we've left behind on extra terrestrial bodies can also stay around for very long. Everything that's been left on the moon for example will basically have to be hit by asteroids to be removed and with how much we've left and how low the rate of asteroid impacts is in our current solar system they'll basically stay there forever, immune to biological or atmospheric sources of decay. These things would be obvious tell tale signs of a previous industrial civilization and even if many of the satellites are destroyed due to Kepler syndrome it still wouldn't be difficult to recognize that these are artificial in nature. Any alien civilization that finds Earth before it is destroyed by the Sun will be able to spot and recognize these things and from that can easily extrapolate that there was once an industrial civilization on Earth, following the same logic given that it only took about 150 years from the invention of the steam engine to the launch of the first artificial satellite we can assume that any industrial civilization in Earth's past would probably have developed space technology and as such leave tell tale evidence in the form of satellites.

There's of course other things we can look at to say that there probably hasn't been any industrial civilization in Earth's past, for example our extraction of hydrocarbons in the form of coal and oil is very noticeable and we have almost used up the entire supply of oil and have significantly reduced the supply of coal. Given how easy these are to use to power machinery we can kinda reason that just because we find them in amounts that are only consistent with us being the first to use them that probably means that there hasn't been any industrial civilization before us. Our coal deposits for example age back to the Carboniferous and many of our oil deposits started developing in later periods. We know that oil would take at least a few hundred million years to naturally regenerate to our current levels and the kind of coal formation that happened during the Carboniferous can't really happen anymore so we can reason with a lot of confidence that there haven't been any industrial civilizations prior to ours.

I feel like they've excluded a few major things for the argument of prehistoric humans. There is significant geographical evidence of a global flood from an asteroid impact in canada when the ice sheet was miles thick. You can look at any map and see the light blue areas between the deep sea and land where 99% of prehistoric civilizations would have existed before the sea swallowed the land. There's also the evidence of continuity in the most ancient of religious stories across the globe. A lot of them describe cataclysmic flooding and weather events that parrot a description of an asteroid impact. There's also an interesting theory that the stories of "people that came before" are the retellings of retellings of communications between prehistoric people and the displaced people from those ancient "advanced" societies. Gobekli tepe predates every timeline for hunter gather society and it surpassed what researchers assumed they were capable of building. Some make the case that they inherited the structures from a much more ancient civilization. They make a similar case for the major structures of ancient egypt, petra and machu picchu. I've even heard someone make the case that rome inherited some of the foundations under their structures. They've also discovered incredible evidence of enormous civilizations in the amazon buried under centuries of plant life after maintaining that humans never had societies there since the beginning of archeology. I'm not saying that the most ancient of civilizations had technology of similar complexity as our own but to claim with any certainty that our historical timeline of hunter gatherers and agricultural societies is accurate is impossible.

Humans are BILLIONS of years old and are NOT NATIVE to Earth. Here is merely SOME evidence suggesting not only a human presence on Earth BILLIONS of years ago, but also suggesting complex human civilisations on Earth BILLIONS of years ago:

* A human skull fragment from Hungary dated between 250,000 and 450,000 years ago
* A human footprint with accompanying paleoliths (stones deliberately chipped into a recognisable tool type), bone tools, hearths and shelters, discovered in France and dated 300,000 to 400,000 years
* Paleoliths in Spain, a partial human skeleton and paleoliths in France; two English skeletons, one with associated paleoliths, ALL at least 300,000 years old
* Skull fragments and paleoliths in Kenya and advanced paleoliths, of modern human manufacture, in the Olduvai Gorge in Tanzania, dated between 400,000 and 700,000 years
* Neoliths (the most advanced stone tools and utensils) in China of a type that indicate full human capacity, dated to 600,000 years
* Hearths, charcoal, human femurs and broken animal bones, all denoting modern humanity, in Java, dated to 830,000 years
* An anatomically modern human skull discovered in Argentina and dated between 1 million and 1.5 million years (eoliths, which are chipped pebbles thought to be the earliest known tools, at Monte Hermoso, also in Argentina, are believed to be between 1 and 2.5 million years old).
* A human tooth from Java yielding a date between 1 and 1.9 million years
* Incised bones, dated between 1.2 and 2.5 million years, have been found in Italy
* Discoveries of paleoliths, cut and charred bones at Xihoudu in China and eoliths from Diring Yurlakh in Siberia dated to 1.8 million years
* Eoliths in India, paleoliths in England, Belgium, Italy and Argentina, flint blades in Italy, hearths in Argentina, a carved shell, pierced teeth and even two human jaws all bearing a minimum date of 2 million years

Curiously enough, several of the very earliest artifact discoveries display a truly extraordinary level of sophistication. In Idaho, for example, a 2-million-year-old clay figurine was unearthed in 1912. But even this discovery does not mark an outer limit. Bones, vertebrae and even complete skeletons have been found in Italy, Argentina and Kenya. Their minimum datings range from 3 million to 4 million years. A human skull, a partial human skeleton and a collection of neoliths discovered in California have been dated in excess of 5 million years. A human skeleton discovered at Midi in France, paleoliths found in Portugal, Burma and Argentina, a carved bone and flint flakes from Turkey all have a minimum age of 5 million years.
How far back can human history be pushed with discoveries like these? The answer seems to be a great deal further than orthodox science currently allows. As if the foregoing discoveries were not enough, we need to take account of:
* Paleoliths from France dated between 7 and 9 million years
* An eolith from India with a minimum dating of 9 million years
* Incised bones from France, Argentina and Kenya no less than 12 million years old
* More paleolith discoveries from France, dated at least 20 million years ago
* Neoliths from California in excess of 23 million years
* Three different kinds of paleoliths from Belgium with a minimum dating of 26 million years
* An anatomically modern human skeleton, neoliths and carved stones found at the Table Mountain, California and dated at least 33 million years ago
But even 33 million years is not the upper limit. A human skeleton found in Switzerland is estimated to be between 38 and 45 million years old. France has yielded up eoliths, paleoliths, cut wood and a chalk ball, the minimum ages of which range from 45 to 50 million years.
There's still more.

In 1960, H. L. Armstrong announced in Nature magazine the discovery of fossil human footprints near the Paluxy River, in Texas. Dinosaur footprints were found in the same strata. In 1983, the Moscow News reported the discovery of a fossilised human footprint next to the fossil footprint of a three-toed dinosaur in the Turkamen Republic. Dinosaurs have been extinct for approximately 65 million years.
In 1983, Professor W. G. Burroughs of Kentucky reported the discovery of three pairs of fossil tracks dated to 300 million years ago. They showed left and right footprints. Each print had five toes and a distinct arch. The toes were spread apart like those of a human used to walking barefoot. The foot curved back like a human foot to what appeared to be a human heel. There was a pair of prints in the series that showed a left and right foot. The distance between them is just what you'd expect in modern human footprints.
In December 1862, The Geologist carried news of a human skeleton found 27.5 m (90 ft) below the surface in a coal seam in Illinois. The seam was dated between 286 and 320 million years. It's true that a few eoliths, skull fragments and fossil footprints, however old, provide no real backing for the idea of advanced prehistoric human civilisations.
But some other discoveries do.
In 1968, an American fossil collector named William J. Meister found a fossilised human shoe print near Antelope Spring, Utah. There were trilobite fossils in the same stone, which means it was at least 245 million years old. Close examination showed that the sole of this shoe differed little, if at all, from those of shoes manufactured today.
In 1897, a carved stone showing multiple faces of an old man was found at a depth of 40 m (130 ft) in a coal mine in Iowa. The coal there was of similar age.

A piece of coal yielded up an encased iron cup in 1912. Frank J. Kenwood, who made the discovery, was so intrigued he traced the origin of the coal and discovered it came from the Wilburton Mine in Oklahoma. The coal there is about 312 million years old.
In 1844, Scottish physicist Sir David Brewster reported the discovery of a metal nail embedded in a sandstone block from a quarry in the north of England. The head was completely encased, ruling out the possibility that it had been driven in at some recent date. The block from which it came is approximately 360 million years old.
On 22 June 1844, The Times reported that a length of gold thread had been found by workmen embedded in stone close to the River Tweed. This stone too was around 360 million years old.
Astonishing though these dates may appear to anyone familiar with the orthodox theory of human origins, they pale in comparison with the dates of two further discoveries.
According to Scientific American, dated 5 June 1852, blasting activities at Meeting House Hill, in Dorchester, Massachusetts, unearthed a metallic, bell-shaped vessel extensively decorated with silver inlays of flowers and vines. The workmanship was described as 'exquisite'. The vessel was blown out of a bed of Roxbury conglomerate dated somewhat earlier than 600 million years.
In 1993, Michael A. Cremo and Richard L. Thompson reported the discovery 'over the past several decades' of hundreds of metallic spheres in a pyrophyllite mine in South Africa. The spheres are grooved and give the appearance of having been manufactured. If so, the strata in which they were found suggest they were manufactured 2.8 BILLION years ago.

What are we to make of these perplexing discoveries? They cannot simply be dismissed. If even ONE of these discoveries is TRUE (and I believe that MANY if not ALL of these discoveries are TRUE), then it changes EVERYTHING that modern mainstream anthropologists THOUGHT they knew about the human species.

We will eventually realize we need to leave our solar system because of one simple fact: Our star only makes a specific number of heavy elements. That means there are NO new elements left to be discovered in our solar system, unless it's from extra solar space debris. Which means if we want heavier elements, we need to create them from scratch, which is very hard. A simpler solution would be to simply find the right stars that produce heavier elements (which isn't difficult), and make a home there. If we want to leverage the benefits of those heavier elements on any large scale, we will need to leave our solar system and go there. If there is one reason to drive us into the stars, that will ultimately be it eventually. So it makes sense that if there was an advanced civilization on earth long ago, they would have long since left to do exactly that.

We assume an advanced civilization on earth would have had materials way beyond our understanding, but in reality, they really wouldn't have. Sure, they could come up with new mixtures that exhibit special properties, but ultimately they would only have access to the same raw resources that we do. Even diamonds can decay, given enough time.

I put off watching this video for a while because in many ways the title felt hella clickbaity. But as ever it's fascinating speculative science, wonderfully presented.

The whole issue the above content deals with is the philosophical burden of disproving a negative. We cannot have proof of it almost by definition, and the fact it's unknowable means this exploration is futile unless some world-shattering proof is revealed. And with all unfalsifiable claims, burden of proof does not lie with the listener but the claimant.

But of course, you guys know this and are having some good fun. It is a fun video and it's given up some creative ideas (leaving a time capsule for a future society, made to last aeons). It's a fun concept!

Thanks again for the solid work!

Wow. You completely missed a few additional concepts that are not unreasonable but bring us a lot closer to identifying intelligent life.

The first is scale. We clearly see evidence of moderately intelligent "aliens" in insects, like ants. Even an industrial insect hive society would leave an incredibly tiny footprint compared to our scale of thinking, and that would be difficult to find at best. Ants dig tiny underground complexes that, when the hive is gone, their living space doesn't last much longer. We'd probably never find that even if it was happening today, let alone millennia ago.

I think you kind of touched on the idea of a form of natural industrialization. For example, crows use cars to run over nuts to make getting at the meat easier. I know, cars aren't natural, but from the crow's perspective, it's using a tool that already exists in what it perceives as its natural world. It doesn't see a car as a machine, the car is just something that exists and has a predictable pattern. We also share an "us-centered" view of the world (as demonstrated by the lack of mentioning such possibilities in this video). We see what we do and assume we can predict patterns of intelligent existence, such as scarring after we mine minerals. What if an intelligent alien could just use the metal without disturbing it, like crows use our cars?

Another form of intelligence we seem to completely ignore is shared consciousness. Just as the neurons in brains communicate via electrochemical signals, some lifeforms share intelligence outside of their own bodies via a variety of transmission techniques. I'll start with ants again as a good example: Ants leave chemical trails to communicate with other ants to help locate food and avoid dangers. Humans are just now entering an age of shared consciousness via the internet. I'm not talking about some new-age spiritual consciousness, but rather a collection of individual processors (us) communicating with each other like neurons communicate with each other. I don't know if this super-consciousness will survive as it seems to be struggling.

I’m a historian and have studied archaeology and paleontology extensively. Prehistory is fertile ground for the ancient alien hypothesis mainly because we do have the story of our deep past wrong. This is mostly due to detection bias. Do most of your digging in the two rivers region because you’re curious about the Bible and most of what you find that is very old is going to be there too. It’s not logically sound to assume that because of that most old human activity took place there or that civilization began there.

There’s plenty of evidence to indicate that more was going on and much earlier than 3700 BCE, but right now conceding it is professionally toxic. The reasons for this are that people have staked their careers on the current story, and two conceding we might have it wrong gives credence to people at the edges of our profession who’ve been saying so for decades now. Some of those people have good ideas, others very bad.

This is what I tell people who ask me about ancient aliens, when I’m asked about it, which is very frequently: Have you seen Lord of the Rings? Tolkien made that all up. Have you seen Star Wars? Lucas made that all up. Simplest explanation is ancient peoples made it all up too.

The next question I’m always asked is why are the stories so similar? And my answer is two fold. First people moved around a lot and shared their stories. Second, there are seed civilizations in antiquity that spread their ideas by war and conquest; and like it or not those ideas and stories are the ones that survived and became a part of our shared heritage.

Again, politics makes it professionally difficult to expand upon this. Point out the similarities between Greek, Egyptian, and Hindu philosophy and someone is going to accuse you of diminishing Egyptian and Hindu history and promoting white supremacy. Point out the massive role winning wars and conquest have had in shaping our civilization and feminists become apoplectic.

So yeah, I’m a historian, doomed to answer ancient alien questions for the foreseeable future because my profession is institutionally committed to not really understanding the past very well. Or at least not talking about it frankly in polite company.

Any large-scale industrial civilization would have used up a large portion of the pristine surface deposits of minerals and fossil fuels that existed at the time. What if a civilization analogous to us made it to space and left behind artifacts on the Moon? The Moon is not geologically active enough to bury anything over time, so would we be able to expect those artifacts to survive the hundreds of millions of years required for us to notice them? If so, we might be able to reasonably say that no civilization advanced enough to make it to space has ever existed before on this planet once we thoroughly scour the Moon. Certainly, they never made a base on it, or anything that'd be easily visible by satellite/probe.

Thus, it seems that any possible prior civilization would have to be constrained to either being totally disinterested in space travel (arguably unlikely) or capping out at a seemingly lower level of technology in comparison to us.

Looking from the beginning of multi-cellular life until now is including a large chunk of history we can be almost certain had no civilization because the life would not be advanced enough. You can almost cut out 100 million years of that 521 million year scale because life would not have had enough time to evolve species capable of civilization. I think it's possible that super ancient civilizations existed on our planet and we see no trace of them today, but that seems unlikely to me.  What seems much more likely to me is that many civilizations have existed all throughout our galaxy, but most, if not all of them are extinct today.  It's possible that once a species gets to the point where they can manipulate their planetary environment like we can today, they tend to self destruct.  Maybe they destroy themselves using ultra-powerful weapons.  Maybe they pollute their planet to the point where it's unlivable.  Or maybe they use up every resource until they can't sustain themselves anymore.  Given our own rate of advancement, it's not hard to imagine these things happening fairly quickly (in galactic terms), like within hundreds of years or less.  The fact that we don't see any sign of alien civilizations today could be because civilizations just don't last very long once they reach a certain stage of technological advancement.  They "live fast and die young" so to speak.

I really don't think it's realistic to think that any other creature besides humans could have been sapient. Humans, being primate placental mammals, seem to have that perfect combination of traits needed to build civilizations: endothermic metabolism, large brains, manipulative hands, omnivorous diet, and flexible behaviors that allow us to learn new things, make tools, and live in complex groups. On Earth, sapient creatures would likely be placental mammals, probably primates, and especially apes ... which is what we are. It's unlikely any other creature on Earth has ever evolved a sufficient intelligence to form civilizations, the way we do today.

Ive wondered about this since I was two years old. It has produced more than just a few existential crisis' and panic attacks. But yea, sad truth is we may possibly never know. For all we know Colossus Penguins (think emperor penguins, but with much larger heads and taller than most humans) might've ruled a pre-industrial empire across the Antarctic jungle 40 million years ago before succumbing to climate change only for their hardier, much smaller relatives to survive to the present day. And something like this scenario might actually be the most likely to leave any evidence at all, crushed under kilometers worth of ice over millions of years. That again leaves the question - where exactly would we look? It's probably no news to anyone that Antarctica is ducking massive, and modern topographical maps made by satellites to scan under the ice are effectively worthless, considering things dont just evenly erode away.

Gott ist in der liebe vollkommen so sollen wir es auch sein, oder das Beispiel vom verletzten Sünder der auf dem Boden lag und alle gingen dran vorbei außer einer, er nahm ihn und kümmerte sich um ihn, so lange bis es ihm wieder besser ging. Oder, wenn dich einer fragt, dem gebe dabei soll deine Linke Hand nicht wissen was die Rechte Hand tut. Oder, wenn einer gegen dich sündigt wie oft soll ich ihm verzeihen, wenn er sich entschuldigt, nicht nur sieben mal sondern siebenundsiebzigmal, da fällt mir das Beispiel mit dem König ein, ein Mann schuldete dem König einen Millionen Betrag, der König hatte Mitleid und Erlass ihm die Schuld dann traf der Mann dem die Schulden erlassen wurden einen anderen Mann der ihm einen kleineren Betrag schuldete, er erließ ihm nicht die Schuld, der König erfuhr davon und sagte was bist du für ein boshafter Mensch die ganze Schuld habe ich dir erlassen, hättest du nicht auch Erbarmen haben müssen.. (Wir wollen ja auch das Gott all unsere Sünden verzeiht drum können wir auch allen anderen verzeihen) Wenn dich einer fragt ob du mit ihm eine Meile gehst, gehe 2 mit ihm. Wenn einer dein Hemd klaut gib ihm noch den Mantel oder wenn dich einer auf die Linke Wange schlägt halte die andere Wange auch noch hin, betet für alle die uns verfolgen liebt eure Feinde. This is a very interesting topic.  It is really cool to think about the fact that our planet can wipe out the record of any civilization in what amounts to a small blip in the timeline of the universe.  Not only the ability to bury the historical record deep in the crust, but the earth's continued recycling of the crust is something of an endless resetting of what is happening on the surface.  It is not a stretch at all to assume that there have been many cycles of intelligent life over the last billion or so years.  One thing the video doesn't comment on is the fact that the human race has advanced at incredible rates in the last one hundred years or so.  The fact that we are on the verge of becoming a multiplanetary race with the efforts to begin a colony on Mars, when we were bound to the earth until the first recorded flight in 1903, it is incredible to think this could occur in less than 150 years.  Humans may be the first to live on other planets in our solar system, and may be the ones that are able to break free of the cycle of being wiped out and turned back to molten rock in our planets every refreshing of its outer crust.  What would be interesting is that if we are able to successfully make it to Mars and do some archeology that we find that we were not actually the first to make this trip.  Of course there could have been multiple intelligent civilizations on Mars as well, and who knows, maybe we are are the descendants of life that came here from Mars, or even some other planet in our solar system, or some other solar system.  It really is beyond our true comprehension how vast time really is, and what may have occurred before us.  We really tend to think in terms of hundreds or thousands of years, or even millions of years, but time is so much more vast than that.  What we understand and have seen is such a small blip in the historical record of our universe that we have likely not even considered how much has occurred prior to our consciousness in this great expanse.  Thank you to Kurzesagt for keeping our minds open to these thoughts and reminding us of how little we actually know, especially in these times when so many seem to think they know it all.

There is another point that is failed to be mentioned. We are not a strange lonely biological occurrence outside a biological ecosystem: “We” belong to a wide family of animals that are interesting enough for our kind of intelligence to appear: monkeys and apes and our (extinct) relatives and then us.

For such extinct civilization you would have to, at least, identify some relatives of such animals that offer some capabilities on such evolutionary direction, if it ever happened. “We” could have never happened and simply stay on a permanent stage of hunter gatherers at most, thus (complex intelligent) evolution is no lineal process with some ethereal goal in some imaginary scheme, but something that only can happen by the serendipity of many things that are beyond that of the predisposition of the species.

Environmental circumstances, our interaction with our (dead) relatives, huge competition with them and then within ourselves (against other humans), may have created an “intelligence-race” that favored those more cunning to take advantage of their circumstances. We (logically) demonize war now, but “war” itself, as the need to collaborate onto a common goal against the competition of others, may be among the elements that helped survive those more alert to absorb and pass the knowledge of their discovered advantages (and that could only happen if our brains were capable enough).

For us humans some argue that a climate change in the past forced our primitive more-chimp-like ancestors to venture into the savannas and take advantage of (more) dead animals’ scavenger to later become hunters, but gave a huge energy boost to build a power (and energy hungry) brain. But that was one of many other events.

We are not even sure (so there are some theories) of why the agricultural revolution happened (may be once human expansion around the world was finally over, contending with other humans forced a more creative approach than the simplistic nomadic hunter-gathering on already occupied areas, thus forcing your land to yield that that you coveted on your own land, and hunger is a huge incentive for observation and invention). When growing plants was easier (and more food productive) than having to kill other humans for that hunting-gathering occupied rich lands elsewhere, then that may have been quite a revolution. Not only you didn't have to die to conquer such lands but the food you produced became (slowly) of more quality.
Then other types of war were waged but that's another story.

Just before I ask you my last question I want you to take a moment to look at your surroundings, really look at them. Perhaps, like me, your finding something to listing to as you fall asleep atop a bed in a nice warm house. Maybe that room, like mine, is painted a brilliant red... RED! I mean who coulda thought of such a thing... welllllll actually my mother dreamt that up 🤣. She invisioned barn red paint, then she turned that thought into reality. Then there's the actual paint itself:

For almost the entire span of human existence my only real option would have been red ochre. Ocher is a sandy clay that contains ferric oxide, but when it contains a-lotta hematite it's a brilliant and almost pleasing shade of red(ish) brown...

Three and a half thousand years ago and provided I lived in India, I could have considered crushing up some rubia tinctorum roots, also known as rose madder. A quite lovely shade it is too, though a tad finger-stainie 😑

Then two millenia ago it would have been vermillion red, assuming I was which is a pigment made from cinnabar- aka mercury sulfate. Great stuff to cover the inside of your home with... actually I think lead (ii) oxide, aka red lead, was just starting to take off in Rome around that same time. Anyone up for ̶h̶e̶a̶v̶y̶ ̶m̶e̶t̶a̶l̶ ̶p̶o̶i̶s̶o̶n̶i̶n̶g̶ death...

Then around six hundred, maybe seven hundred..
ish.... years ago there were some absolute animals that's were crushing bugs to dye their clothes red. Count me out.

I do know that just a centry and a half ago alizarin we first synthesized in Germany. And I guess it's a little cool that its probably alizarin thats coloring my doors.

Thats enough about red, though you caught me red-handed: I've read a lot about red, Red.

I just so happened to also glance at my favorite little buddy, Lee ❤. Now his glass tank is made up of 9 pieces of float glass, which were made by combining river sand which could have come from anywhere (btw its just fine ground silica dioxide, this is the base glass structure) with soda ash (sodium carbonate, which is flux and lowers the melting point by ALOT), some limestone (calcium carbonate, gives it strength), and a pinch of dolomite (calcium magnesium carbonate, for that pinch of "more extra strengths")... oh yeah, and I seem to recall alumina (aluminum oxide) is in there, can't remember.

Anywho, those all get mixed together and put in a big @$$ crucible. But before the magic can happen someone, somewhere else had to shoot air cannons at the ground so they could listen SUUUPER CLOSELY to how the earth raddles. That way they know where they sould start digging their couple-uh-miles-deep hole so they can recover the remains of creatures that lived half a billion years ago (thats 4% the age of the universe by the way). With their essence-of-earth-fart gas in hand they are nearly ready to go! They just have to add some essence-of-deadly-fart to it, ya know... for safeties sake...

So they take the earth-life-fart out of the ground, purify it so it's just methane which as we all should know is a highly flamibe, possibly explosive gas. Then they mix in some methanethiol, which ca naturally be found in bad meat, good cheese, bad breath, goose death, and pretty much anything else that could be decried as "pure stank". Guess I should also mention its slightly more flammable then methane... oh, and it's fair bit more explosive.... aaaaand its INCREDIBLY POISONOUS... AAAAANNNNNNNDDDD it once your in the "danger zone" your sense of smell and taste are the first things to go.... but don't worry: the irreparable liver damage, lung damage, kidney damage, skin irritation, comma, diarrhea, kidney stones, convulsions, soar throat, anemia, disorientation, pneumonia, brain damage, nerve damage, muscle damage, muscle weakness, palpitations, seizure, death, and slight eye irritation.... oh ya and if it gets into the sea it's like Fukushima 2.0 × a billion. But on the bright side it doesn't cause cancer!

Anywho,.we take that Megadeth mix and blast it on that aforementioned crucible of sand. Eventually the silicon dioxide turns into MOLTEN BEACH LAVA! ™
ᴾᵃᵗᵉⁿᵗ ᵖᵉⁿᵈᶦⁿᵍ

That beach lava is then floated across a lake of molten zink, which is collected by attacking rocks with lightning (or electrolysis if your lame)... then that post-floated-glass is cooled and cut, not necessarily in that order.

Those chunks of glass are then packed into a truck, or a plane, or a boat, or a comically large backpack, and sent anywhere from a few feet to more-than-one-earths-widths away where they get get stuck together with glue which, fun fact, is made of a polymer who's bade structure has the same elements and ratios as glass, it just gets a little extra stretch.

Once that's done it gets shipped literally around the world, from one factory, to a warehouse, to a store. Then, despite it being delicate, going tens of thousands of kilometers, and having countless look-a-likes... somehow when the store ordered 1 "4'x2.5'×18" front access reptile enclosure" they got it... despite hundreds of people, buorcrats, war zones, lions, pirates, train bandits, and lord knows what else it made it. For someone to purchase... that I then purchased from them because these buggers are EXPENSIVE, and I couldn't turn down a $50.

Then there's the devil's vine I've got growing in there which is native to South Asia, the spider plant from West Australia, a Chinese Evergreen from New Guinea, a teenie Norfolk Island pine from Norfolk Island, and a Bonsai from Japan (which they stole from China).

Then there's the mesh top... it's from somewhere.

The bulb has more of that lovely red pigmentation we talked about earlier, it's also got a tungsten wire (which probably came from Vietnam or China), a brass fixture (China), a plastic bit (China), a glass bulbular shaped bulb (China) which has aluminum (China) electroplated (100% China) on the interior for efficiency... oh and it's also filled with a gas that was extracted from the atmosphere.... which is accomplished by two hair-pin-trugger hydraulic pumps pushing and pulling a few helium balloons worth of helium back and forth. Yes, that's actually how its done.


And then there's my love himself, Lee. He's my labyrinth het snow red tail boa. He is absolutely gorgeous, a gem to hold, hes super curious, and odd as it sounds he loves people! He "surfs the room" as I call it. He chills with someone for a bit, then reaches out to get hold of someone else and chills on them for a bit before moving on to someone else. Probably good he's chill af because some people FREAK when he tries to get on their shoulders... I get it though. This video doesn't do too good of a job at really pointing out the problems with this.
The fossil record isn't our only source of information about the past.
We also have evolution as a mathematical concept. We have DNA as a method of backtracking genealogy.
And while we can't tell for sure what life forms all exactly existed in the past, there really isn't much room to speculate on a highly advanced civilization. The further we go back, the more primitive life forms are. Their senses are weaker, their survival strategies are less capable to adapt. A high level of intelligence is costly in energy. Today we breath high energy air, generated by older life forms and the higher energy bodies of other life forms to keep our massive brains working.
In terms of space aliens, there is no reason to believe, they would come to earth specifically and not to any of the other planets. Yet we don't see traces of that anywhere. Of course that doesn't make it impossible. It's just even more of a stretch than having aliens somewhere in the galaxy.

Why would something like the Voyager craft last longer than a satellite at a Lagrange point? As they're travelling at a little over 10 miles per second, and interstellar dust is going to degrade them at a greater rate than if they were sitting there. Obviously some dust and general debris could well be travelling much faster, but then it would have the combined velocities.

The Voyager spacecraft are relatively small. A previous civilisation could have launched huge space telescopes, assembled them in orbit and then sent them to a Lagrange point, and they could be the size of a skyscraper, which means that, even after a few million years, the tangled wreckage could still be there. Also, if they were that advanced, there could well be the remains of Moon bases, built mainly submerged, in tunnels for us yet to find. The same could be true with submerged Martian bases.

However, in order to develop such a civilisation, they would have left incredibly huge scars in the landscape, as they mined for materials, that, even after millions of years, would still leave some kind of sign (the Vredefort crater and dome are still detectable 2.1 billion years later. OK, that was left by an asteroid that dwarfed the one 65 million years ago, but the point is that truly huge scale events can still be detectable, unimaginable aeons later.

The idea of lost civilizations seems very plausible. Take what we are currently doing and extrapolate it into the future. We are striving for biodegradable and recyclable materials, starting to embrace and design not just for planned obsolescence but for intended degradation and eventual disintegration to limit the impact of manufactured goods, and building with natural materials or those derived from nature. Our plastics are being made from organic materials and becoming compostable and our advanced technology is growing smaller and smaller. Taken to the logical extreme, all of our cultural artifacts may soon reach the point that they would cease to exist in the years following any catastrophic event. They would just degrade or be so small that they are either destroyed or unrecognized as anything not inherent to nature.

A lot of extinction events in the past aren‘t very well explained, thus they're still being debated among academics, so it's entirely possible that they're related to prehistoric civilizations.  Unnatural radioactive elements could possibly be undetected since they could've been decayed into non-radioactive elements in the millions of years passed, or they're just somehow be detected as naturally occurring, or the ancient civilization could very well have used radioactive elements that cause practically no radioactive pollution, like hydrogen fusion.  It’s also worth noting that (as I heard from some other sources, please correct me if I'm wrong as the info I got was mixed) there‘s a blank interval of about 100k years in human history, which almost no evidence of human civilization/tribe/group was found.  Considering modern humans are anatomically surprisingly similar to ancient humans, and (relatively modern) humans took only about 10,000 years to go from basic agricultural civilizations to our modern technological super-empires, it's not very convincing that humanity didn't advance much between that 100k-year time period.  Also, think about the ancient civilizations, like the Sumer, the Egyptian, the Chinese, etc.  We aren't that far in the future, but far enough that we don't know much about them and thought of them as far-behind or underdeveloped (don't know the right words), yet archaeological results tell us that they're surprisingly advance, sometimes even to a point where not even modern technology can (easily) replicate or explain.  So, is it that absurd to think that there could be super technologically advance empires before us?  I don't think so.

Regarding extraterrestrial civilizations in the past, there is a lot of indirect evidence for this. For example, the buildings of the Maya, Aztecs and Incas (or some of them). The patterns on their walls, sculptures and buildings themselves are executed with such precision that they are clearly ahead of their time. Or, for example, the Egyptian pyramids, which in ancient times could not be built without the use of more advanced technologies, and there is also a lot of scientific evidence for this. In this matter, everything is not as clear and simple as it may seem at first glance. Perhaps aliens have visited our planet before and built these structures, or helped people build them. Or there was a civilization before us that had made significant progress in some narrow direction of technology, but without discovering electricity or the like. Personally, it seems to me that one or another option is quite likely.
