The problem with this theory is that there is no evidence that any life was moving toward that level of intelligence or complexity in the fossil record. For another intelligent race to appear, there has to be some fossil evidence of life moving in that direction. The other part is there is no evidence of life being that complicated to produce intelligent life until the last few million years. When the first hominids started to appear on Earth.

If there is any evidence to be found it would likely be in the form of nuclear energy. In fact, an ancient nuclear reactor was actually found in the Oklo region of Gabon in 1972. It was using cooling techniques that humans were not yet using by that time, but the consensus became "it's natural" because no one could believe that anyone could have built it despite scant evidence that a nuclear fission reactor could form "naturally" in the surface of the Earth's crust.

There was also a case of radioactive isotopes found in mines which should not exist on the Earth without technology, but this too was considered natural because it couldn't be anything else. At least in this case there could be another explanation: Radiotrophic bacteria have been found in mines that do eat radioactive material so there could be an unknown biological process involved here.

Now, of interesting note, are ancient religious texts that describe a nuclear bomb:

"Gurkha, flying a swift and powerful vimana hurled a single projectile charged with the power of the Universe. An incandescent column of smoke and flame, as bright as ten thousand suns, rose with all its splendor. It was an unknown weapon, an iron thunderbolt, a gigantic messenger of death, which reduced to ashes the entire race of the Vrishnis and the Andhakas. The corpses were so burned as to be unrecognizable. Hair and nails fell out; Pottery broke without apparent cause, and the birds turned white. ...After a few hours all foodstuffs were infected... ...to escape from this fire the soldiers threw themselves in streams to wash themselves and their equipment."

Poetry aside, these stories do sound like they could have been in reference to a nuclear war. When combined with physical evidence such as ancient nuclear reactors and isotopes that should not exist it makes me wonder how much more evidence might exist.

tl;dr/spoiler alert: NO
Speaking as a professional archaeologist, while this is a fun thought experiment, there are plenty of geological, chemical, and cosmological constraints that preclude the existence of complex/industrial civilizations of sufficient antiquity to have been erased from the paleontological record. Facing the terrifying reality that at least in this solar system we are the first species to industrialize and "escape the surly bonds of [gravity]" means we have no help from the Earth sciences in avoiding whatever Great Filters lie ahead. But yeah, being more sustainable and leaving less [per capita] impact would be great. Don't worry, with nearly 8 billion hominin meatsacks alive today, even the tiniest individual traces will add up to enough cumulative evidence of our existence for many millions of years to come. And hey, don't forget, we've only got about 500 million years of plate techtonics left, so very likely some of today's continental crust may still remain to remind future archaeologists & paleontologists that we were here.

Just an aside here on the subject- British author Gerald Kersh wrote a short story  titled "Men Without Bones"- As Kersh relates it,  two explorers, investigating a plateau hidden in an almost inaccessible part of the Amazon Jungle, discover the remains of a giant machine, possibly several million years old, that turns out to be a crashed spaceship. Exploring inside the vast wreck, they find in the debris a large semi-circular plate of some unknown hard metal that proves that the ship came from Mars. And they also find what seem to be the descendants of  the Martian expedition that servived the crash- Revolting dwarf mollusk men- Round, boneless humanoids, alien and malignant,  that suck the blood out of any living animal they swarm. Armed, the explorers keep the boneless monstrosities  at bay.  The explorers plan to immediately return to civilization with with the Martian plate, but one man is killed by a poisonous snake, and the other just barely makes it out of the jungle alive, catching a fever and  loosing the Martian plate in his desperate struggle to survive the journey out. Proof gone, nobody believes his story, thinking it nothing more that a fever induced delirium. Later, after he's recovered, the explorer  realizes something disturbing-  The disgusting boneless things living on the isolated plateau aren't the Martians-  They're Earthmen,  the descendants of the few survivors left after the shipwrecked Martians and their fecund progeny took the Earth away from them. That's right- The monsters are the true Earthmen.  We are the Martians.

Those are some pretty dramatic assumptions you're making about human history and deeper history. The level of confidence in such statements about how rapidly certain signs of civilisation would decay or blend into the background are too high in my view. Already your 'facts' on 300k year old humans doing absolutely nothing but hunt and gather until 10k years ago are disproven by the historical sites in Turkey, particularly the famous Gobekli Tepe where megalithic sties were built 11.5k to perhaps 14k years ago. Even that 300k year date was very recently pushed back from only 200k years which was believed until the past decade or so...and that 300k number itself may end up getting pushed back further when we find more evidence. Even in the robustly explored areas of early human habitation in Africa, one of the most studied places on Earth, we continue to find out new things. This 'presentism' of our current knowledge is a very limiting perspective where somehow the channel comes across as though we've reached the end of knowledge through overconfidence in expression of quite temporary 'facts'.

The ending of the video is also very strange where you make the very error your saying not to make...a lack of evidence is not the same thing as evidence of lack. The world is enormous, landscapes and biomes have changed, and relatively little of the Earth's geology, much less the ocean's geology has been explored to look for such signs, if they can be found at all without fading into the background. Many a small scale agricultural society with pottery and even primitive metal usage could have emerged with all evidence wiped away over time with our currently limited technology and scope of examination.

How much of the currently underwater continental shelves which used to be above water when sea levels were much lower have been explored? How many core samples, drillings, or other attempts have been made to seek out artefacts of human habitation in such places? Would our current methods even work? the slow and careful process of years using tiny picks and brushes from terrestrial archaeological sites clearly are not applicable in the ocean. the answer is very little of this area has been explored, despite it being the absolutely most likely places for such prior human civilisations to exist, not to mention deeper layers which might contain traces of non--humans from tens or hundreds of millions of years ago. Far too much certainty and confidence is put into this 'lack of evidence' without acknowledging we also 'have not even looked' yet.

If we say 'evidence is impossible'....then say 'don't think about it' that's just baseless speculation.

Kurzgesagt has created an impossible standard and encouraged us to close closed our minds to evidence you did not consider? There are many forms of evidence other geology where one might dig up a stone tool, including a large number of anomalous genetic findings we have yet to explain with many genes connecting far flung populations. Connections which might be explained by there having been global sea faring societies in our distance past. How else could genes from Europe be found in Australia and New Zealand going back 30k or 50k years without any connecting genetic lines showing migration in between, far too many and genetically similar to have so many odd variants co-evolve by chance....yet there would have been and currently are quite reasonable sea routes for some ancient Greek technology level global civilisation with a few peaks and valleys in their capabilities compared to the ancient Greeks.

Even today with Wade Davis' work and documentaries we have see the wayfarers show us it does not take advanced tools or knowledge to navigate vast swaths of the ocean. The channel would make do to step outside of establishment knowledge bases in order to consider other ideas, even if you discard them it would be far better to show some process of consideration and debate of ideas than to express apparent ignorance of key archeological insights over the past 30 years.

We know for a fact many cataclysms affected humanity over our 300k year history. Without evidence does not mean we can know nothing as we can reasonably infer things based on our own example. The idea that humans did nothing at all for 290k years and had no rises or setbacks in technology, agriculture, building, animal husbandry, pottery, stone tools, etc. is itself the more preposterous idea. The ruinous effects of time are severe and we know processes of geology and changes in sea level and habitable landscapes which would make it extremely unlikely for us to find anything.

What we DO HAVE is evidence that people were anatomically the same for nearly 300k years...with perhaps some major changes in the 40k-50k year range. It is quite possible people truly made no advancements at any point in our history, but through what is known we can reason it is more likely that pockets of civilisation emerged and were wiped out.

Great video, but I think for the last category there is a missed opportunity to talk about space archeology. In principle, satellites in geo are semi permanent, the exosphere just doesn't go up anywhere near that high. And similar to how it seems fair to assume aliens would recognize universal constants like hydrogen emissions or prime numbers, I think it is also fair to assume a sufficiently advanced civilization would eventually put things in geostationary orbit. It is too useful and obvious to accidentally not discover if you've already figured out space tech.

To that end, I think we can look at geostationary orbit and at our own moon to put an upper limit on the technological complexity of any hypothetical prior civilization. I found it surprisingly difficult to find any direct analysis of ultra long term perturbations for satellites in geo orbit (I think because the math is extremely sensitive what with the 3 body problem, and there is no compelling reason to invest the computational resources to analyze something so sensitive and so trivial). Also, my orbital mechanics is admittedly rusty, but given perturbations like lunar gravity, solar gravity, solar photons, and the solar wind, I don't see a reason to expect all of a prior civilizations geo satellites to decay in at least a few hundred million years (anyone reading this with direct experience in eon timescale orbit evolution, please weigh in as I'm really curious about this one).

Similarly, the moon doesn't have plate tectonics, vulcanism, erosion, or any other weathering processes besides solar photons and solar wind. To my knowledge, most moon rocks are about 4.5 billion years old (i.e. roughly the age of the moon). We have pretty complete maps of the lunar surface and we haven't found anything seemingly synthetic. So either we're the first ones there, or whoever was there before us did an incredible job of cleaning up after themselves.

In light of both of these factors, I think we can put a pretty strong upper bound on prior civilization technology as "at least not space faring". That is to say, as far as I can see, humans have likely gotten the deepest into the tech tree for any beings that have lived on this planet so far (obviously excluding the dolphins and the mice).

Hey this video is great but begins with the common myth of the "agricultural revolution"

Human agriculture was done in alluvial planes and other niche regions, or was done purely for creative experimentation for thousands of years before any massive civilizations began, so a consciously practiced and consciously avoided human activity can't really be called a revolution, especially since the timeframe here is thousands of years

This also necessarily includes the myth that humanity develops along neat distinct stages : hunter gatherer to agricultural society to city and so on

This is simply not true as a precept, many cultures who practiced agriculture to any degree avoided what we consider normal farming today, only practiced seasonally, or adopted farming and then consciously gave it up in favor of a hunter gatherer type of lifestyle

The view of human history espoused in this video is thus prescriptive, it assumes that bc we are at the "end" of history always right now, that everything leading up to now was some sort of incrementally staged puzzle that was always going to develop on these lines

As I've state above, this prescriptive view leaves out countless examples that would contradict or add needed nuance to this narrative

That, in which ever way humanity will go down, we will not have destroyed the planet completely, and that life and intelligence will find their way after us once more.

Humans would also be in the explosion of fossils. There are more than 50 million humans deaths a year and that number is only going to go up as the population ages.
Let's compare T. Rex? An animal we have quite a few fossils of despite it only having for a few million years.
There were around 20,000 T. Rexes at peak population. Really not very many. They had comparable lifespans and reproductive rates to humans. So if we ignore the infant mortality in each and focus on the number of adult and subadult skeletons we find, we would expect T. Rex to be making around a 400-ish dead per year. Let's call it a billion T. Rexes to ever die as adults.

Well, homo Sapiens already have a hundred billion dead. Even if you discount infant mortality, there's still at least tens of billions of humans who have died globally. A healthy number of which would be in all three periods of human existence.

That number will go up by billions before the average viewer of this video dies.

Ergo, a hundred or so million years from now, we should expect every continent to provide at least a dozen complete fossil skeletons from humans of each time period. Probably quite a bit more though, because humans often bury their dead, which, while it doesn't guarantee fossilization, may make it more likely.

There is one more place where an industrial civilization may have left a mark that would be noticeable for millions of years. Outer space. Any large spacecraft or satellite in high earth orbits or on the surface of the moon would likely survive for millions and possibly 10s or 100s of millions of years. Over really long time scales some would be perturbed into solar orbit and would be nearly impossible for us to detect with current technology, but we would easily detect reasonably sized spacecraft in high earth orbit, and we might detect large structures on the Moon (although dust accumulation from meteor impacts would hide smaller things on the Moon). It seems safe to say we are the first Earth based civilization to perform any significant amount of space travel.

I think we can rule out any advanced civilizations on earth before us, at least anyone using plastic. Microplastics will be seen in our strata for hundreds of millions of years.
As for agriculture, there is a tiny possibility before 23 000 years ago. Just in the last few months, German experts have noticed that Neanderthals cleared large area of lands around where they were living 120 000 years ago and they kept that land cleared for thousands of years. We don't know why and agriculture is unlikely but not impossible.

I don't think anyone before Homo Erectus had the intelligence to create anything you could call a civilization even in it's broadest terms. Lack of evidence is of course no evidence in itself but the brain size of anything before them were rather tiny so it is extremely unlikely. Later Homo Erctus had rather large brains though.

The only other real possibility besides Hominins would possibly be some kind of octopus. Some kinds of them are surprisingly smart and unlike land animals they don't tend to leave much fossils. I don't know if "civilization" would be the right word there but they can communicate some basic things to eachother so I guess there is a tiny possibility they could have had some organized thing going on in the past. It wouldn't be something we would recognize as a society though.

In completely unrelated, isolated cultures across the planet there's always some level of commonality; small and mischevious or magical humanlikes, large and hostile humanlikes, demons and dragons. They're often oddly specific about these as well, and the commonalities are specific as well. I would venture that these things were real enough for people to tell stories about them for tens of thousands of years, and they were local enough for each to be different. Almost every culture has either massive scaled beasts flying through the air or giant raptors doing the same. The elegant elves and faeries of Aenglo, Welsh and Celtic mythologies have much in common with Germanics (being the magic and small statures of fae) and much in common with ethereal, magical humanlikes from both Eastern and Meso-American mythologies. Demons are a universal constant in human mythology and we seem to have some universal evolutionary fear or revulsion of human-like creatures that don't quite look or act right, perhaps indicating some sort of ancient civilization of human-likes that tried hunting us. Hell, it could even play into the, for lack of better words, xenophilia humans have towards human-like creatures in fiction/mythology that are very clearly not-human, but humans nonetheless consort with them.

What I'm saying is that there's no material evidence but there is evidence from stories, and we largely discount these stories as being non-historical despite any evidence that would support their veracity, because they're "non-scientific" sources.

The difference being, the K-Pg boundary is marked by a layer of Iridium, indicating a strike from an asteroid or comet.  The Holocene-Anthropocene boundary will be marked with a layer of microplastics. A technological, industrial civilization will recognize its source as artificial. They may be puzzled at how we created so much plastic with relatively little petroleum in earth's crust, though.

I hate the conspiracy nuts. When scientists talked about this thought experiment they obviously took it to mean they really was a civlivation before us. But no, that is absolutely objectively impossible. We'd see something if they'd used any of the natural resources of the planet. Not to mention, they wouldn't have had fossil fuels either as those are only really avalible for use pretty recently, way to recently for them to have been used before. And if someone else had used them in the past, we wouldn't have them to use now.
The point of this thought experiment was to think about what would be left to look for when and if we ever get to other planets in other solar systems. There we could get somewhere and find it lifeless, or with life but no intelligent life, but it could have been the long before we got there. This was to look for that. Not to suggest it may have been a civlization on earrth before.

Something to note is that since the Cambrian explosion animal life seems to be getting progressively more intelligent, at least from what we can tell in the fossil record. For example, a smart bird nowadays (like a crow) is probably leagues smarter than the smartest dinosaur 65 million years ago.
This may be because as ecosystems and organisms become more complex, higher intelligence is needed to navigate the environment (and cooperate with your own species) competitively.

If this trend is true, humans may be the latest advancement in a long trend of increasingly more intelligent animals, and so this might explain why there is no evidence of prior civilizations. This would also mean we likely won't be an anomaly, and many more intelligent animals may evolve.

There's also the growing evidence that other animals (particularly some dolphins such as orca and bottlenose) may also have human-level intelligence, and so they could be the 'alien race' we so desperately want to meet.

As an archaeological scientist, I think this an incredibly succinct presentation that explains why you never hear about ancient aliens in academic discussions. It's not that we are 100% sure that ancient aliens didn't exist. It's that, in over a century of research, there has yet to be any clear evidence for such a phenomenon. We become frustrated by ancient aliens theories because such theories often contain significant logical fallacies that are invisible to many people that aren't actively researching the past. This is because our work contains lots of details that are often spread across hundreds of kilometers of sites, and only connect to give us fuzzy details about a society's cultural variation and patterns. For example, studying pottery fragments from different sites can tell you the specific clay mixtures used to make a specific type of vessel, or the sequence of steps used to produce that vessel. Variation within these techniques at a single site can tell you how many pottery workshops there might have been and whether or not we have some kind of standardization. These link together between sites and give us a picture of how their pottery economy might have functioned in the past and how it might have linked to other crafts. This is extremely important for understanding how long-term climate shifts may have impacted these societies, since the subsequent layers often represent adaptations of older techniques (depending on the time and place).

If you were to research the Middle Paleolithic (starting ~50,000 years ago), this suddenly becomes far more complex because you can't tell if your deposits are contemporaneous. For us that are researching the Bronze Age, layers can represent centuries, but in the Paleolithic, layers can represent several millennia. People used to be hunter-gatherers, and a well-preserved cave deposit could represent 5,000 years of use that all appear to be a single layer. This means that Paleolithic archaeology and Paleontology both require a lot of attention to details because tiny microscopic differences can be incredibly meaningful. The reason that nobody thinks we had ancient civilizations at this time is because despite all of this attention to detail, nobody has found anything that would indicate this

An interesting dichotomy I've noticed is peoples' tendency to think on either the micro or macro scale about every issue. I think it's at the root of a lot of disagreements in society today. Some people complain about systemic racism, others say they don't see racism. Some complain about climate change, others see it snowing outside. Some think we should all get vaxed, others are willing to take the risk. Some think the US has been around for a long time, others think multi-celled organisms just got here. And it's not as simple as saying the macro thinkers are "right", because it's not that simple. There are edge cases at the micro level that need to be considered. It seems like most people's worldviews are somewhere on a spectrum between macro and micro, and I think humans need to recognize this and get better about considering the entire spectrum before we will be able to come to any agreements and not destroy ourselves.

one thing i really like to think about (gives me the brain tickles) is that there is so much unknown history humans have. for all we know, there may have been another set of civilizations prior to Sumer, Egypt or China. and not just those big civilizations. maybe here, in southeastern Europe, in the Danube's plain, where there were once large forests, maybe someone had a kingdom. before the Indo-Europeans ever came, a strange land with strange people tried to make itself into something. maybe for a while their life was good and their technology up to date. they sang songs, told stories, built homes. they had families, they had enemies, they had a special way of cooking the meat and a multitude of days of celebration over the year. right here, where i am now, today. maybe it was the same for somewhere on the Baltic shore, or the Iberian peninsula. maybe China had many many more dynasties before even those we consider to be legends. maybe a civilization flourished at the source of the Nile as Egypt did at its mouth
so many maybes, all so beautiful yet subtly melancholic that i can't help myself

I think it would be incredibly unlikely for past industrial civilizations to become sustainable so quickly that they leave no trace in the geological record. Humans have only industrialized for about 200 years and we've already left a distinct mark in the long term geological record that will last for a very long time and should indicate to any future geologists that it is not natural to see such a massive spike in CO2 in just two centuries. This is a mark that we haven't found anywhere else in Earth's history. If any other civilizations existed, they never almost certainly never industrialized. However that question is one we may never answer. Like the video said, the imprints that a non-industrial civ would leave would erode quickly on the geological timescale and are potentially undetectable today.

One thing this video doesn't adequately address is 'unnatural' chemical compositions of rock layers. Even in agrarian societies, you had smithing and other processes (particularly involving high-temperatures) which would produce chemical positions in remnants which would be difficult to explain in any other way. Take iron for example, natural native iron is almost exclusively found in meteorites. I presume any post-Iron Age equivalent society would leave behind relatively high concentrations of pure iron in particular places, which wouldn't fit with a pattern of meteorite impacts.

Also, whilst fossilisation requires niche conditions, preserving cut gemstones or carved stone isn't anywhere near as difficult. If an intelligent civilisation previously existed, we'd presumably find a bunch of clearly-unnatural carved knick-knacks embedded in particular rock layers.

You also probably would have very particular geographical concentrations of any remains, aligning to the positions of continents at the time of the civilisations existence and the geological experiences of landmasses since. These would be a further thing that would be difficult to explain. (For example, any evidence of Bronze-Age Humanity would be concentrated in present-day China, India, Mesopotamia-Egypt, and non-existent in Siberia or Amazonia.)

First off, Banded. Iron. Formations.

These are billions of years old and the easiest available source of iron, RN. Even a "sustainable" civilization would have gone through an unsustainable period and mined for ressources in the same way we do now. And they'd have mined those after going through even easier deposits which were also present. They are also a marker of the precipitation of iron in the archean oceans with the appearance of oxygen.

Secondly, we have a prettu complete geological record. We don't have missing links somewhere in the record, up to pretty much the precambrian. What this means is we've got traces of catastrophic events. Chicxulub? We got a worldwide irridium layer showing it. My point being - someone would have left a mark, if they'd been as far as we are. Plastics, nuclear waste, these aren't human-only problems, they'd be any civilizations' problem.

There are several problems with the "answer" to the question given in this piece.

First, the process of archeology. As can be seen by numerous extant examples and significant university studies to the contrary, the dating of modern human habitation sites around the world are still maintained as beginning in the 7th millennium BCE. That there are numerous religious sites which date many thousands of years older indicates that the desire to maintain a narrative is more important than getting the actual chronology correct. Archeology has become so politicized that science takes the back seat. A great example is the dating of the Sphinx. It is fascinating that every single monumental work of ancient Egypt displays the general ratio and proportions of a design ethos and the relative structural component relationships of animals and people. Yet, the Sphinx is a creature that is so disproportionate that it forces any objective observer to conclude that the head was reworked from some more ancient form and into its current form. That the stone work shows signs of weathering consistent with its construction 4000 years earlier than accepted by the Egyptian Board of Antiquities just means that the studies by experts in Geology are unimportant compared to politics.

Second, having a city does not not mean it is durable. Let's use the fossil record as an example. You know there are deer in the wooded area by your home. You walk the woods often. In your entire life you've never seen a deer carcass not the skeletal remains of a deer. There are reasons. But here's the point. If, 250 years in the future, all deer gave died out, no one will ever believe that deer existed in your present location because in the future no one can find their remains. So, remains do not last...nature reacquires them.

There's a great show called life after people. One of the great takeaways from it is that our modern cities would be largely turned to dust within a few thousand years after our hypothetical disappearance. The most ancient habitation sites around the planet point to at least 20 millenia BCE. Therefore, any prior civilization would have existed well before that....that is pre-glacial melt. That is more than enough time for them to turn to dust.

Third, there are about several million square miles of land area that were slowly lost following the last glacial maximum. If any people formed cities then they would like us have populations heavily skewed to coastlines. Therefore, any remnants of those cities are buried under massive quantities of silt and are under 300 to 400 feet of water. We are looking in the wrong place.

Thankfully, the internet is available to help the ignorant. But only if they know to do research first.

Modern humans have left traces of our civilization that will last essentially forever, certainly many times longer than the sun has left to burn, but the chances that those traces will ever be discovered by any intelligent thing be it biological or some other sort of "alive" we can't even imagine at this time is vanishingly small. The Voyager and Pioneer probes along with New Horizons and other probes that have been given enough energy to escape the sun's gravity will orbit the Milky Way more or less forever and if you had a hand in constructing any of these incredible machines you will have achieved a sort of immortality that is very rare.
You see, we each experience 3 deaths. There is the personal death. That is the death of our body. Then there is the death of the last person who knew us, and finally, though it doesn't actually involve anyone dying, there is the destruction of the last trace of our existence. It could be the destruction of the last record that we existed, say when the name on our tombstone finally becomes illegible, or the last object we had a hand in creating is destroyed by time.
Some will live longer than others with this 3rd life. For example, Narmer, the earliest Egyptian Pharaoh we are fairly sure actually existed lived more than 5000 years ago, yet the woman who was the mother of the guy who made Narmer's first bed was probably forgotten not long after the death of her last grandchild.
Does it make you feel insignificant to realize that in 200 to 500 years not a trace of your ever existing will be left anywhere in the universe?
Consider the people who matter to you. They are in the same boat as you. Does the fact that no trace of their ever existing will be left anywhere in the universe 500 years from now change how much they mean to you one bit?
Just because your life won't matter 500 years from now doesn't mean your life doesn't matter right now. Your life does matter right now. That is all that counts.

Interesting and I highly agree. One further factor, however, seems to have been missed: viz. if an advanced civilization preceded ours then why wouldn’t they also become space-faring? And the obvious first stop would be the Moon. The Moon doesn’t suffer erosion in the same way as that of Earth and, if an earlier advanced civilization visited there, then there would probably still be relics of that. So far we’ve found none … which isn’t to say we won’t at some point … but the lack of any sort of imprint on the surface of the Moon seems to me to be clear proof that (if a non-human Earthan civilization did predate our own) it never got to the technology level that would allow it to achieve orbit or attempt to make a moon landing. Or maybe I’m wrong.

To my mind, 3 things prove no civilization has reached the space age on earth in the last 500 million years. 1) everything is where we'd expect it to form naturally. The banded Iron deposits put down well over a billion years ago, the deposits of Uranium and Thorium, the Carborniferous oil and coal deposits, all of them are where they should be naturally. 2) No layer of radioactive material. It wouldn't be visible to the naked eye, but the deposits of radioactive materials put down by open air nuclear tests would last millions of years as a detectable and planet wide layer. 3) no space artifacts. We'd expect to see things like the remains of rovers and other exploration vehicles on the moon. It's an obvious first target in space exploration, and probably the best place to preserve artifacts imaginable. No air, no moisture, just micro-meteorites and the occasional moon-quake.

As for an earlier civilization, it is perfectly possible. The dinosaurs were the dominant group of animals for well over 100 million years. After they died out, we immerged from the new dominant group in less than half that time. It certainly is possible.

Coal is geologically unique because it was formed when plants figured out how to make cellulose and for a long time nothing could break it down. Coal was formed when these massive piles of old cellulose would catch on fire. This meant all coal on earth was formed in this tiny period, and will never be regenerated, unlike oil. This lends credence to my general theory that a hardline of “humans couldn’t have known or done x, y, or z by this date” or “ancient aliens are the only way this feat could have been accomplished” is really dismissive of what ancient humans could achieve.  How many Archimedes, da Vincis, Newtons, et al could have existed over our millennia of existing? How many were wiped out by disease or genocide with their knowledge lost to superstition or accident? I don’t mean unbelievable stuff like magic, but maybe things as simple as making a seaworthy boat, creative art or storytelling, or making something recreationally ephemeral yet technologically advanced like a kite.  These things may seem anachronistic past a certain point and I argue that it shouldn’t be if physics are an understandable and intrinsic part of existence.  I think ancient humans were more mobile, more clever, and more creative than we give them credit.

The first man-made tool dates back 3 million years. Homo Sapiens has been in nature for only 150,000 years. We are talking about the industrial revolution here, but if we consider that we have an evolution spanning more than 3 million years, the probability of an intelligent life reaching the industrial revolution and disappearing will be very low. There is a huge difference between 300 years and 3 million years. Moreover, if we consider that it is easier to reach more primitive technologies, it is possible for such a society to exist. If such a society exists, it will be close to impossible for us to find them. I think we should accept that we are alone in the world because we can observe the existence of an industrial society more easily and we have not seen such a thing yet. if there is an industrialized society we will never know if they exist as it will be impossible for us to find them. If we have to approach it scientifically, it is meaningless to defend something that we have no proof that it exists. Until we find evidence to that effect, I think it would be more accurate to "assume" that they are not exist.

It is highly unlikely that there were any previous civilisations as all the coal (which was a key ingredient to our own species industrial revolution) that exists was all created at the same time in what was effectively a 1 off (350-300m years ago) ecological/geological event.

I'm unsure about Oil & Gas formation, but there used to be plenty of that lying around, and we have manage to use a lot of that natural resource up as well, and you would suppose that a post industrial civilisation would not have left that much for us to use now if they had existed.

Whether there were any pre-industrial civilisations that is more difficult to say, but it is some what certain that there was no post industrial civilisations before us.

About the record an industrial civilization would have for future scientists: fossils: Yes, but why should future scientists associate cow bones or rat bones with civilization ? Also: Almost none of these bones will fossilize.
Fertilizer: This will be gone in a few years. Even if it goes kilometers down in the ground. You know, because of bacetria that eat this stuff.
Mining metalls: Our scrapyards become the mines for future civilizations. Everything will be crushed and grinded under millions of tons of rocklayers. And its rusting. your bike will be as natural as a brown rock in a few million years. And about the empty mines with a lack of ore: the mines will be collapsed and nobody will notice a lack of something.
plastic in oceans: Will also be eaten by bacteria in a few hundered years. unless it's Teflon or some other fluorinated shit. this lasts longer. But almost nothing of the plastic waste in our oceans is fluorinated.
radioactive elements: They are natural rescources. Nobody would think of civilization if you find uranium on any planet in the universe. Oh, what about unnatural amounts of it ? What is unnatural ? Every planet has different element ratios. And the artificial elements we created decaying faster then we like it. We even found natural nuclear reactors. Yes, in some places on earth there are high enough concentrations of uranium that a few million years ago a fission reaction started, at the age of the dinosaurs. in Oklo, africa.
CO2: this gas varied since the beginning of our planet. We had higher concentrations and lower. And we even had drastic changes like now before. CO2 is absolutly no indication of intelligent life on a planet.
increasing the acidity of the oceans: Again: This is gone in a few hundred years with the help of bacteria. Or geological processes. And our oceans were even more acidic in the Cretaceous period. So, nothing unnatrual here.

However i think that something that is most commonly overlooked when talking about the rise of intelligence on earth is the active energy of an ecosystem; we can see that for the entire mesozoic era, the vast majority of bodysizes (at least those found in the fossil record thus far) were large and developed several adaptations to survive and thrive in a world full of other large animals for hundreds of millions of years. Intelligence, however, is a more specialized adaptation that requires a less energetic environment. That is during the Cenozoic era when there was a marked decrease in bodysizes, especially in those of predators. This likely gave more leeway for smaller species to compete and develop the myriad adaptations that allowed intelligence to emerge, albeit relatively slowly. That's what always comes to my mind when this topic is talked about!

Concerning the importance of agriculture for the development of civilization (around 1:30) and our society: this relation is not so undisputed anymore among anthropologists.

See the recent work of David Graeber & David Wengrow "The Dawn of Everything" or James. C. Scott's "Against the Grain".
Both were quite eye-opening readings claiming that complex civilizations did in fact predate agriculture and that most people who shifted from hunter-gatherer lifestyles to sedentary agriculture did in fact have to suffer a decrease in both: quality of nutrition and even in their life expectancy.

It would be interesting to see you tackle the popular narative of our hunter-gatherer ancestors living in small bands, ignorant of such aspects of civilization as navigation, architecture and government (to cite just three examples that you gave).
This idea that civilization as we know it is contingent on the development of agriculture is of course, a very widespread view, and has been for a few centuries. But it's worth considering that it is a view that is based on 1) mere speculation by European philosophers in the 16th and 17th centuries, and 2) on lack of archeological evidence to the contrary.
Well, archeological and anthropological evidence has been steadily piling up over the past 100 years which suggests that the lives of our hunter-gatherer ancestors were far more complex than we imagined. Instead of small, isolated bands of inbred egalitarians (or witless pawns under the yoke of a tribal chief) scratching out a meager existence, humans 50 000 years ago were doing pretty much the same things as humans are today, except with simpler tools and materials that have long since turned to dust (mostly). So, far-reaching trade and contact over thousands of miles, complex social institutions and relatively monumental architecture built by huge numbers of coordinated labor are all present in pre-agricultural times.

A book that synthesizes much of this evidence is "The Dawn of Everything" by Graeber and Wengrow. The writing can at times be a bit biased but the sources they cite are worth studying further.
Humanity my be temporary, but our shame is eternal.

There's absolutely nothing in physics, chemistry or biology that prevents the possibility of prior advanced (or medieval) civilizations having existed on Earth in the past, and now being lost to time. So to just dismiss it because "woo-woo" is stupid.
What people dont understand regarding archaeology, is that what we find, and CAN find, is less than 1% of 1% of what existed.
Billions of T-Rexes and their close relatives existed during their time, across a few million years. Yet we havent, nor can ever, find billions of intact skeletons. We've found a few hundred at best.

The fact that we find ANYTHING AT ALL from past human civilizations such as the sumerians, is simply because they're so close in time, relative to the age of the planet. And we dont find 100 thousand arrowheads, we find a few dozen, and make estimations based on those finds.
Think to yourself how many arrows bows and swords must have existed in the ancient world, think about Xerxes army in Persia, several hundred thousand strong, each one with a pristine sword, spear or bow.
We dont find 100 thousand swords, we cant ever find that, because 99.9% of them have eroded or become lost to time.

So just because we dont find any evidence of a past civilization, does not mean they didnt exist.
What is even remaining for us to find and make any conclusion based on, is a fraction of a percent of what actually existed back then.
And the further back in time you go, the fraction diminishes exponentially.
People dont realize this, they think we've found millions of velociraptor skeletons. We havent. We've found a handful.
A handful out of billions that existed during those ancient eons.

And just because we cant find or prove it, doesnt mean we should just ignore any thoughts about it.
There's a common misconception about the mainstream scientific principle which is "if you cant prove it, it didnt exist or isnt worth speculating about". Which is entirely wrong. Speculation is healthy, it opens the mind to possibilities that are currently unknown and unproven, but might become proven with enough effort in the future.

If gallileo didnt speculate about distant worlds, he'd never have built his telescope.
Speculation is not the antithesis of the scientific principle.
It's what feeds its direction for decades to come.
As long as we remember that speculation is possibility, not evidence.

And of course this applies to interstellar civilizations as well.
No matter how pessimistic, OR optimistic you are about CURRENT living civilizations in the galaxy, there simply must have existed far more civilizations than CURRENTLY exist, simply due to the passage of time, and how the past is always a greater "volume" than the present.
We're not only interested in finding currenly alive civilizations, we're also interested in finding xenoarchaeological artifacts from the countless of previous civilizations, drifting through space. And that's where most of the volume will lie, in the ancient derelict artifacts, not in the current functioning living technologies.

When you seriously sit down and think about this, and do the math (adopt the drake equation to factor in migration and colonization, as well as multiply the end number by how many civilizations must have become extinct in the past), you realize that something like Oumuamua actually being a relic, is not implausible to think at all. The universe must be teeming with artifacts drifting around, accumulated over billions of years.

Q: What is your opinion on technology? Is it something that brings revolution or it’s just a delusion?

A new religion has evolved in the global culture. It’s called Scientism. Even though modern science has absolutely nothing sensible to say about the reality we live in, the general population is convinced that science has explained away the need for God and religion.

Scientific theories like abiogenesis and evolution, even though they are pure and unalloyed myths, are being taught in all educational institutions of the world as scientific facts.

Who has decided that technological expertise is the best way to measure our ability to understand the reality we live in? Those who are influential in defining peoples' realities - the producers, scientists, the media, politicians, etc. -- have made technological advancement the barometer of human progress. They claim that the advancement of technology is the most noble pursuit of the human race, that it has made the world a better place to live in.

As proof, they list all the consumer gadgets we use and are dependent upon - computers, cell-phones, televisions, DVDs, cars, and so on - and say that the intelligence to build these things shows that we have advanced our understanding of nature and how she works far beyond our ability in the middle ages.

But is this assertion correct? To build a computer, one certainly requires advanced knowledge of physics and chemistry, but these disciplines describe only a tiny part of the reality we perceive. A far greater part of reality is our conscious experience of it -- something most people don’t even think about.

Few people ponder the fact that their understanding of the world is conditioned by the culture they grew up in. They automatically take it for granted that the way they perceive the world is the correct one, and that nature is best described in physical and chemical terms.

Modern science is very useful for making technology, in fact, it’s the only thing it is good for, and when we live in a world where the masses are kept in awe and reverence of technological wonders, science is, of course, a most important undertaking.

But the jubilation of modern people over the newest technology is no different from the gaping wonder with which people in the middle ages looked upon sorcerers and magicians firing off sulphur and gun powder. The magicians did this to dupe their audiences and secure their comfortable hold on society.

In the middle ages, in the West at least, the regents of society kept people in ignorance so they were easy to control and manipulate, and today the exact same means are used to enslave people in ignorance. In the global culture the slaves have just been upgraded to a middle-class with their own house and car.

People still slave their lives away in boring jobs and are marred by the same endless worries and miseries, people have always suffered from. They are still being ground down by taxation, victims of greedy politicians, exactly like they’ve always been.

There is no basis for saying that advanced knowledge of mathematics and physics enables a person to better understand the world any more than the cave dweller of some 2000 years ago who worshipped nature and various gods.

If the modern culture is based on a better understanding of the world, why is it ruining nature and her inhabitants at an alarming rate? If modern man is more advanced in his understanding of nature, why is he sawing the branch he is sitting on?

Despite the so-called advancement of modern society, people are till not able to transcend their mental conditioning. The proof is that modern society does not produce people with evolved consciousness. Rather, we see the exact opposite taking place - in direct proportion to the advancement of technology, people have become more and more base and idiotic in the way they treat and relate to each-other.

Some years ago, WHO published a report saying that the biggest health crisis facing the world in the new millennium is that more and more people will be born with mental defects. Is that the symptom of an evolved society?

Society, as it is, is not equipped to facilitate self-realized human beings. What need does a self realized person have for the plethora of useless products being produced by the few conglomerates that control world consumerism? Such enlightenment would indeed negate the necessity for the technological advancement upon which the world's finances now rely.

That is why, in the current global culture, a deliberate campaign exists to transform people into atheists. In such a culture, religion is being ridiculed and has been replaced with politics. Instead of voting for a particular religion, the public now votes for politicians, who are mostly hired by those multinationals with the biggest checkbooks -- all in the name of serving the people, of course.

The modern, global culture has already made the whole world into one big marketplace - a worldwide altar where technology is worshipped as the new opium of the masses.

Being fed endless propaganda from Hollywood where technology saves the day, we quickly forget that technology, despite assurances to the contrary, cannot save us from the onslaughts of nature. Time and time again, technology comes up short in the fight against nature.

The new high-priests of society, now clad in white frocks instead of black, fail to comprehend how the mechanisms of nature work. And how could they? They also suffer from the misunderstanding that everything is dead matter, and are restricted by the assumption that their knowledge of physical laws can explain the world.

Yet more important than understanding how physical matter works is the understanding how consciousness, false ego, intelligence and mind work. These make up a much greater part of the reality we perceive. As long as we fail to understand the difference between matter and consciousness, we cannot even be said to have evolved beyond animal consciousness.

That's why atheism is dangerous - it keeps the consciousness trapped in a 3-dimensional world of matter. It keeps the self from its rare mission in the human life form - to understand consciousness. It cultivates a perception of life where the consciousness cannot see itself - a deception where the self being absorbed in matter forgets itself.

Every individual is duty-bound to alter their consciousness and connect it with the whole - Sri Krishna. While Srila Prabhupada was a nitya-siddha, he was also a social revolutionary, as was the Lord he served - Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. The political correctness that predominates in the world and passes as social etiquette should not stop us from assisting him in his mission - to silence the atheistic class of men, and to inundate the world with Krishna Consciousness.

Krishna says:

The living entities in this conditioned world are My eternal fragmental parts. Due to conditioned life, they are struggling very hard with the six senses, which include the mind.

The living entity in the material world carries his different conceptions of life from one body to another, as the air carries aromas. Thus he takes one kind of body and again quits it to take another.

The living entity, thus taking another gross body, obtains a certain type of ear, eye, tongue, nose and sense of touch, which are grouped about the mind. He thus enjoys a particular set of sense objects.

The foolish cannot understand how a living entity can quit his body, nor can they understand what sort of body he enjoys under the spell of the modes of nature. But one whose eyes are trained in knowledge can see all this.

The endeavoring transcendentalists who are situated in self-realization can see all this clearly. But those whose minds are not developed and who are not situated in self-realization cannot see what is taking place, though they may try.

— Bhagavad-gita 15.7–11

There's one type of evidence from agriculture/empire civilizations that wasn't mentioned in the video. Or rather, something similar to it misleadingly applied only to industrialisation. That's homogenisation of species and its rapid spread. There are some particular species (and even sub species) of plants and animals that agricultural civilizations found more useful than others. Those few species experienced a massive population increase and were rapidly spread across entire continents, and even between them. So if the fossil record shows that a particular genus exists in only one area, and with many different species of it there, in one moment; and in the next layer there's only one species of it left but it's become worldwide, then that is a huge signal that something very unusual has happened.

Are There Lost Alien Civilizations in Our Past? Of course, we refer to them as pre-Inca and pre-Aztec, these are the civilizations that built all the massive temples you hear about, the Inca and Aztec did not possess the technology to cut at perfect 90-degree angles and move a single stone that weighs 500 tons, it was the civilizations before them that did this, and we do not know who they were, or even their names, they are shrouded in mystery because there is nothing to excavate from that time period. You can see this all over the world at important historical and archaeological sites, such as Temple Mount in Jerusalem, where the current temple is built upon 2 previous temples, which are also built upon a large single stone slab that has an estimated weight of over 2 million pounds.
